I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  As part of its mandate to formulate and implement national laws, policies and standards 
concerning  local  government  operations,  the  Philippine  Department  of  Interior  and  Local 
Government (DILG) has been working for several years with local governments to develop 
performance  measurement  and  assessment  tools  to  help  local  governments  improve  local 
governance  and  service  delivery.  DILG  would  like  to  strengthen  the  existing  performance 
measurement framework to enhance local government development, improve access to and 
use of data by stakeholders, and provide input to national policy making on local government 
issues. Hence, the Government requested Asian Development Bank (ADB) assistance during 
the  2002  country  programming  mission  for  advisory  technical  assistance  (TA)  to  support 
development of an enhanced local governance performance measurement system. A fact-
finding mission was fielded in September 2002 and reached broad understanding with the 
Government  on  the  goal,  purpose,  scope,  implementing  arrangements,  cost  estimates, 
financing plan, and terms of reference for the TA. The TA framework is in Appendix 1.1 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  The  Philippines,  a  forerunner  in  Asia  in  introducing  comprehensive  decentralization 
reforms, enacted the Local Government Code (LGC) in 1991. The code devolves to the local 
level  significant  responsibilities  for  delivery  of  services  in  areas  including  agriculture, 
environment, local infrastructure, health and urban services, and places them at the forefront of 
efforts  to  reduce  poverty.  The  State  of  Local  Government  Address  in  20012  notes  that 
decentralization  has  encouraged  greater  innovation  at  the  local  level,  strengthened  local 
management capacity, and promoted greater cooperation with the private sector and Local 
Government  Units  (LGUs).  However,  despite  these  achievements  the  full  benefits  of 
decentralization, in terms of improved service delivery particularly to the poor, have yet to be 
realized as local governments face a number of resource constraints, including limited financial 
resources,  underdeveloped  capacity  for  planning  and  resource  management,  and  weak 
information systems. 
 
3.   Enhancing  LGU  capacity  to  deliver  quality  services  hinges  on  long-term  capacity 
building aimed at (i) improved assessment and collection of own revenue to reduce dependence 
on the Internal Revenue Allotment; (ii) strengthening planning, budgeting, resource allocation, 
and expenditure and financial management; (iii) improved quality of public administration; and 
(iv) better governance through strengthening accountability and transparency mechanisms. All 
of these will require improvements in the quality, availability, management, and use of data in a 
coherent  performance  management  framework.  This  is  consistent  with  the  growing  shift, 
internationally, toward introducing performance-based planning, budgeting, and management to 
enhance the efficiency and effectiveness of government services and the development of tools 
and systems to monitor and improve performance.  
 
4.  A well functioning performance management system based on accurate and timely 
information  will  assist  LGUs  to  perform  their  mandates  in  a  number  of  ways.  Improved 
collection,  analysis,  use,  and  dissemination  of  data  on  government  capacity,  development 
status, and performance support the principles of greater accountability, transparency, and 
participation. It provides information to citizens on what their local government is mandated by

law to provide and enables them to provide feedback on the quality of services received. It 
enables local governments to identify and analyze problems in service delivery, and serves as a 
key input to planning and resource allocation decisions. Enhancing local revenues requires data 
on the current capacity to generate income, collect taxes, and analyze policy and administration 
gaps. Private sector investment at the local government level is constrained by a lack of 
information on local government performance and creditworthiness. Performance data enables 
better  pro-poor  targeting  of  development  assistance  by  responsible  national  government 
agencies and international development partners. Information on development status, local 
government capacity and program effectiveness also assists national level policymaking on 
local government issues. 
 
5.  To address some of the information gaps, DILG has been working with LGUs and 
external funding agencies for several years to develop performance and assessment tools for 
local government. For the most part, however, the tools were designed to help DILG determine 
the capabilities and limitations of LGUs in the performance of their roles and responsibilities 
under  the  Local  Government  Code,  consistent  with  the  DILG  mandate  to  formulate  and 
implement  policies,  standards,  and  projects  to  promote  local  autonomy  and  oversee  local 
government operations. In addition, a recent study conducted by the Philippine Business for 
Social Progress showed that 12 funding agencies have been working since 1995 with 20 
partner  agencies  (public  and  private)  to  develop  performance  indicators,  resulting  in  the 
generation  of  almost  400  indicators  of  local  government  performance  across  17  sectors.3 
However, most of this data is not analyzed and made available to LGUs in a form that feeds into 
improving services. Such a proliferation of indicators is unwieldy and inefficient, duplicates 
information, and places undue burdens on LGUs to supply information. Despite the number of 
indicators it is extremely difficult at present to get a consolidated picture of the status and 
performance of LGUs as not all indicators are disaggregated below the provincial level, data are 
maintained by a number of different institutions, not all data is publicly available, and the 
accuracy and timeliness of data has been questioned.  
 
6.  At the joint Government-Donor Forum on Local Government Benchmarking in January 
2002 it was agreed that the Government needed to form a technical working group to compile 
an inventory of the numerous indicators maintained by national government agencies, and to 
propose a system for consolidating these into a workable, integrated performance measurement 
system. The technical working group4 nominated DILG as the appropriate focal agency for 
monitoring local government performance, and agreed that DILG should enhance its local 
productivity and performance measurement system (LPPMS)5 as the primary database on local 
government performance. The LPPMS was developed during 2000 as a first step in compiling 
performance data on good governance, administration, social development, local legislation, 
local economic development, and environmental management. The system currently stores 
information provided by LGUs on a self-assessment basis, but has a number of limitations as a 
management tool. It was agreed that although the Department of Finance, the Department of 
Budget and Management, and Commission on Audit would continue to develop and maintain 
their own databases on local government financial indicators, this information would also be 
integrated  into  the  enhanced  LPPMS,  to  be  known  as  the  local  governance  performance 
measurement system (LGPMS).

7.  In addition to the LPPMS, DILG previously initiated two related projects, which will be 
integrated into the LGPMS. The local development watch system was piloted in 36 LGUs and 
collects social, economic, and environmental indicators that can be reflected diagrammatically 
to provide an overview of the development status of LGUs. The citizens satisfaction index 
system is intended to provide citizens feedback on the quality, coverage, and accessibility of 
basic services, but has not yet been developed. The integration of the three systems, plus the 
exchange of data with other national government agencies, will (i) enable the validation of data; 
(ii)  provide  more  detailed  information  as  inputs  to  LGU  planning,  resource  allocation,  and 
management; (iii) allow the benchmarking of local government performance against agreed 
standards;6 (iv) improve the analysis of LGU capacity and development status; and (v) improve 
the usefulness of the data to a variety of stakeholders. 
 
8.  The first phase of developing the LGPMS is anticipated to be completed in May 2003, so 
that information generated can be used in the LGU planning and budgeting cycle for 2004. The 
first phase involves upgrading the capacity of DILG offices to assist LGUs to collect, collate, 
analyze and disseminate information and to upgrade the technical capabilities of the information 
system. The project is divided into four interrelated components: (i) system design, (ii) system 
development, (iii) system testing and capacity building, and (iv) data gathering. The activities 
under this TA will complete the system design and development components of the project. The 
other components are being funded by DILG and other donors, primarily Australia Agency for 
International  Development,  Canadian  International  Development  Agency-Local  Government 
Support Program (CIDA-LGSP), and United Nations Development Programme.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
9.  The long-term goal of ADB’s assistance is to enhance the capacity of national and local 
government to improve local government management, service delivery, and development. The 
TA will assist the Government to strengthen the performance management framework for local 
government  by  providing  tools  and  systems  for  assessing  local  government  capacity  and 
performance. 
 
10.  The TA consists of three interrelated components: (i) the design and development of an 
integrated database with enhanced capacity for the analysis, management, and sharing of data; 
(ii) upgrading of hardware in the national and provincial offices of DILG to improve the efficiency 
and effectiveness of the information system; and (iii) the development of user guides and 
manuals. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  Systems Development. Since an overarching objective of the integrated database is to 
consolidate performance information and reduce the reporting burden on local governments, 
before software is developed, agreement will be reached between relevant national government 
agencies on the core design features, data sharing, and use of outputs from the system. 
Discussions  between  relevant  agencies  are  under  way.  The  analysis  and  selection  of 
appropriate software is a critical step in the development cycle, as the architecture of the 
LGPMS will determine the capacity of end-users to manage and manipulate data, analyze LGU 
performance,  and  share  information  with  other  stakeholders.  The  LPPMS  system  was

developed as a Microsoft-Access-based application with limited ability for users to analyze data, 
search the database and produce the variety of reports required. The structures, data capture 
processes, and other components of the three existing systems will need to be analyzed to 
determine the most appropriate system design, taking into account issues of compatibility with 
data systems of other government agencies and the need to have the system work with the 
Internet. 
 
12.  Data Integration. The core LPPMS system was focused more on meeting the needs of 
Bureau of Local Government Supervision (BLGS) than those of LGUs and other stakeholders. It 
also relied exclusively on self-assessment by LGUs without validating information from other 
sources,  particularly  from  citizens.  Integrating  data  from  all  three  existing  systems,  plus 
information from oversight agencies such as the Department of Finance, Department of Budget 
and Management, National Economic Development Authority, and National Statistics Office) will 
improve the integrity of the output and enable users to get a broader picture of the economic, 
financial, social, and environmental status of LGUs. An integrated database increases the 
analytical capability of the system and will allow DILG to develop a single set of tools and 
procedures for data collection, management, and use. However, the three existing systems 
were  developed  with  different  software  applications  and  data  currently  residing  in  those 
databases needs to be merged into one database. Capability will also have to be built in to 
import and export data between databases maintained by other government agencies. 
 
13.  Data Management. The management and dissemination of data has been inefficient 
owing to capacity constraints. Some data have to be transmitted in paper form between the 
local, provincial, regional, and national levels and entered into the system more than once, 
which reduces the integrity of the data. For example, although almost 90% of LGUs provided 
information  during  2000,  the  national  database  contains  data  on  less  than  75%  of  these, 
although the information is available at other levels. The processes of collecting, compiling and 
analyzing data have to be significantly speeded up for the data to be useful as a management 
tool. The provincial DILG offices act as the data hubs, as the collection, collation, storage and 
dissemination points for data from all LGUs within the province. However, only 57 out of 79 
provincial DILG offices have computers available for running the system. Limited capacity exists 
for maintenance of the provincial databases or user support. The BLGS maintains the national 
database,  compiling  provincial  data  and  integrating  data  from  other  national  agencies, 
performing data analysis and disseminating data to stakeholders. Its current systems lack the 
storage and analytical capability to effectively manage the enhanced national database and 
disseminate  timely  information.  The  TA  will  support  enhanced  data  management  and 
dissemination, which will necessitate some hardware upgrading, for BLGS and the provincial 
offices to (i) ensure basic functionality of the new system; (ii) test the software developed; and 
(iii) increase accessibility of data to DILG and LGU users. 
 
14.  Capacity Building. Training will be required for LGU officials in using the upgraded 
system  and  in  interpreting  the  data  to  improve  planning,  management,  and  development 
activities. Most capacity building for LGUs will take place through user manuals and training by 
municipal local government operations officers. Customized training materials will be developed 
and workshops conducted for (i) provincial staff who will collect and encode data; (ii) municipal 
local government operations officers, on analyzing data outputs and preparing reports; (iii) 
database administrators; and (iv) technical training for staff who will need to maintain and 
customize the software applications. This TA will support the development of user manuals for 
database administrators and technical personnel, as other training activities are being funded 
from other sources.

5 
C.  Cost and Financing 
15.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $290,000 equivalent, comprising $152,000 in 
foreign  exchange  and  $138,000  equivalent  in  local  currency.  ADB  will  provide  a  grant  of 
$200,000 to cover the entire foreign exchange cost and $48,000 equivalent of the local currency 
costs.  The  TA  will  be  financed  on  a  grant  basis  by  the  ADB-funded  TA  program.  The 
Government will finance $90,000 equivalent of the local costs, through the provision of office 
accommodation and facilities, use of equipment, administrative support, remuneration and per 
diem of counterpart staff, counterpart staff travel, and staff training. CIDA-LGSP will, in parallel, 
finance $160,000 to support the project management unit (PMU) and provide further capacity 
building. A detailed cost estimate is provided in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  DILG will be the Executing Agency. The TA will be led by the LGPMS team, which is the 
PMU within the Bureau of Local Government Supervision. The team will be led by a full-time 
project manager funded by CIDA-LGSP and will be responsible for organizing the technical and 
administrative aspects of the TA, and for supervising coordination with other activities linked to 
implementation of the LGPMS. PMU staff will support the work of the consultants and facilitate 
the consultants’ work by ensuring access to relevant data and documents. The TA consultants 
will provide full support to the project manager. The project manager will report to the Director, 
BLGS. 
 
17.  The TA will require inputs of approximately 4 person-months of international and 5 
person-months  of  domestic  consultants  with  expertise  in  database  management,  systems 
development, and programming. The consultants will be engaged by ADB in accordance with its 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for the 
engagement of domestic consultants. The TA consultants will be based in Metro Manila and be 
required to travel to provincial offices of DILG as necessary. Equipment will be purchased by the 
PMU in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement. The outline terms of reference for 
the TA consultants are included in Appendix 3. 
 
18.  The TA is expected to commence in November 2002 and be implemented over 7 
months, to be completed in May 2003. The consultants will produce (i) an inception report at the 
end of the first month, including the design specifications of the data model, structure, and 
agreements for data sharing with other national agencies; (ii) a draft final report; and (iii) a final 
report at the end of the assignment, including data dictionaries and operating manuals. Training 
and dissemination workshops will be hosted by DILG to familiarize stakeholders with the system 
and to provide training for DILG staff and LGUs in the use of the enhanced database. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $200,000 on a grant basis to 
the  Government  of  the  Philippines  for  Support  for  the  Local  Governance  Performance 
Measurement System, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Senior Application Developer and Team Leader (4 person-months) 
 
1.  The senior application developer will report to the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
project officer and to the local governance performance measurement system (LGPMS) project 
manager. The developer will be the team leader and be the leader of the software development 
team. The developer will have had proven experience in software application development, 
database management systems, design and development of large integrated management 
information systems and experience specifically with Microsoft Access and MySQL. Experience 
with local government database management systems in the Philippines and with Management 
in Information Systems will be an advantage. Responsibilities will include the following: 
 
(i)  supervise  of  the  software  development  team,  which  includes  the  application 
developer  and  staff  seconded  from  electronic  data  processing  service  and 
Bureau of Local Government Supervision,  and provide expert input on system 
design; 
(ii)  ensure  completion  of  all  coding  required  for  successful  completion  of  the 
application in accordance with the design specifications; 
(iii)  assist the  Department of Interior and Local Government (DILG) to finalize the 
LGPMS design specifications and development work plan; 
(iv)  design and develop the database program according to specifications, including 
the input and edit module, querying, reporting, and import and export modules; 
(v)  establish a data model for the LGPMS taking into consideration stakeholder 
inputs and existing data structures; 
(vi)  produce of the inception, draft final, and final reports as required by ADB; and 
(vii)  ensure effective communication with the project management unit, and with ADB. 
 
B.  Application Developer (5 person-months) 
 
2.  The  application  developer  will  report  and  provide  support  to  the  senior  application 
developer. The application developer will have had proven experience in software application 
development,  database  management  systems,  and  experience  specifically  with  Microsoft 
Access and MySQL. Experience with local government database management systems in the 
Philippines  and  with  Management  with  Information  Systems  will  be  an  advantage. 
Responsibilities will include the following: 
 
(i)  ensure  completion  of  all  coding  required  for  successful  completion  of  the 
application in accordance with the design specifications; 
(ii)  assist  the  senior  application  developer  to  finalize  the  LGPMS  design 
specifications and development work plan;
